Santa Monica Bay.name: Santa Monica Bay
reviews: The Pier and Santa Monica are fantastic and a must to visit. Lots to do for families and an unbelievable beach. Lots of places to eat and drink

One of the best bay to visit in the evening for sunset. We had the best sea food in a little cafe. The place seemed to have lots of entertainment but didn’t spend much time as it was very windy that evening.

Having lived in Los Angeles for 3 years and many visits later, I still love Santa Monica Bay. In fact, when I overnight in the Los Angeles area, I always stay in Santa Monica in part because of the panoramic views of the bay extending to the north and south. On a clear day it is stunningly beautiful.

The path along the Bay is convenient and active. It is not only good for exercise but delightful people watching. The views are constantly changing as the sun rises and then sets beautifully into the Pacific Ocean at sunset. You can even enjoy the view and the Bay by walking along Ocean Avenue which looks down on the Pacific Coast Highway the beach area.

Most special of all is the sunset. It is spectacular and special. My sons used to crawl along the beach while my wife and I drank a margarita or cold beer. And on the day my youngest son died, I was in Santa Monica when I heard the news. That beach and the sunset will always be very special for me.

Don't miss the opportunity to walk, run or simply sit and relax at Santa Monica Bay. It is very special.
Show less
This place is very famous for photography lovers and usually a lot of tourists from all over the world are seen here.
A lovely and beautiful beach town

With a great view to the pacific ocean and clean blue water, this town is amazingly clean and well organised. Open performance with Tom Petty music filling the air, surfers around and amazing murals all over, makes it an enchanting getaway. again a must visit

Before heading to LAX, decided to relax and take a stroll on the Santa Monica Beach - it was first thing in the morning, not busy, sand was freshly grated and cleaned, simply breathtaking scenery. Next time we'll definitely enjoy this stretch of beach more and rent the bikes and peddle the 26 mile path. A must do when in Santa Monica.

Beautiful beach. Clean and not full of bums like our experience in Venice beach. I would feel comfortable bringing my grandchildren here.
Is a place just to see the ocean and tanning

the beach is full of people, there are no places to eat or to drink something. if you want just to bath or to get tan is the place to go. on the pontoon you will find different artist selling their creations.
We came here because of Billy bob Thornton and Goliath.. The Pier is nice, the beach wasn't filled bums on my day but that doesn't mean they aren't there. be safe.
We got here around 9am, before anything had really opened, so we went for a walk along the beach and down the pier. It's a really nice area for a walk when the weather is nice
So much to see an do
Santa Monica Pier is well worth a visit. So much to see and do. We hired bikes and rode up to Venice Beach. A very memorable day and easy public transport links by bus or metro train.

Not a beach person but it’s nice to be by the sea. The Pier reminds me of the East coast, Wildwood, Ocean City and Atlantic City back in the day. Great shopping in town, good food and comfortable places to stay.

Santa Monica is a beautiful beach and fair ground. It wasnt as big as i thought but it was still nice. It takes about an hour but its a lovely walk to the buzzing Venice Beach. Plenty of shops and restaurants along the pier. Recommend Bubba Gumps! Small fair ground but still good especially for the kids.

We had breakfast at Bubba Gumps. The food was good, the vserice very friendly and the view fantastic.
Been here on my last trip to the west coast. Definitely a good spot, the pier is always packed and it's a very lively place.
Lovely old fashioned pier with a roller coaster and other amusements. Beautiful clean beach. Not many places to eat and a bit pricey.
Not much activity on a Thursday evening

We were disappointed that everything was closed at 8pm on a Thursday evening. Only bubba gump shrimp was open, the rides and all stores were closed. Would love to have gone back during the day but we didn't have time.

We enjoyed several hours walking along the pier and Oceanfront Drive. It was a lovely, sunny day, not too warm, with clear blue skies. It was fun people watching, enjoying the local talent, seeing the people work out at Muscle Beach. We'll try to come back on our next visit to the LA area.

Little beach area with flavors and vibes

There were many little shops on the boardwalk and bike / scooter rentals.

We had Eggslut (always amazing!!!) which is closer to Venice Monica beach then walked down the boardwalk to Santa Monica Pier. The little community here is welcoming and there will be a lot of people hustling products of all sorts here!

A little northwest of the Santa Monica Pier, there were a ton of typical shops and food that i see in many different countries.

This beach is beautiful, worth coming to see if you have at least 3-4 days during your visit. I'd recommend getting the bikes for only an hour, there arent an insane amount of things to see and prices are quite inflated at the shops that cater to tourists.

Never a dull moment here, with endless characters of all sorts running, cycling and walking up and down, also a glorious beach
Great way to escape LA reality

During a recent convention I took the Metro from downtown LA to Santa Monica. Although I would like to have spent more time, I walked the Santa Monica Pier, listened to some good musicians and stuck my toes in the Water at the official end of Rt. 66 highway. A great place to unwind!

We spent the afternoon and early evening here with out family of 5 (boys ages 7, 11, and 16) just last week. Lots to see and do. Boys loved muscle beach as well and the equipment kept them quite entertained. I would not recommend walking all the way to Veince Beach though as even in the afternoon, it was a bit sketchy and my boys had a LOT more questions than I had answers for.

A beautiful day on the bay
Be prepared for big crowds on the weekend. Queues were not too long to get on the Ferris wheel, a lovely open air experience.

While we only had a few days in LA, Santa Monica was one of our favourite places. Reminded me a lot more of Australia except the sand goes on for miles. Not sure if the long walk to the water is a good or bad thing! Clean, well to do and beautiful. Definitely worth a visit on any visit to LA. SANTA MONICA is alive, active, even passive...whatever you want it to be. The beach is clean, and one could walk miles; the air is clean, crisp, & fresh. Near the beach are fantastic & oh so many restaurants, bars, & parking (all of these require more $$ than a small town).
The beach itself is great also for children to swim, make sandcastles, & imagine. A quality stroller would provide your tiny ones & breath of fresh air, and just listening to the waves is calming. A stroll is also great for couples, who may need a good long talk, walk, & be alone. Bicycling is great; make sure it is a BEACH BIKE. Please note that when Hollywood was in its heyday, Santa Monica was THE place. In fact, the famous ROUTE 66 was created for people anywhere from Chicago to Santa Monica. I traveled that route a dozen times, & the arrival to this elegant beach was the climax. You must include this if you are in the area.
Show less

A very romantic place to visit during sunset. Even with the crowd, the place looked very lovely and serene. I went here capturing GoPro footages and the view is just stunning.

Never tried the rides and the food here. I must say, just plain walks here will keep you full and satisfied.
Show less
The area is clean and picturesque. Park and a beach and the pier. Also many nice shops and restaurants when you are ready for a stroll. Try to spend one day here.

This is one of the most beautiful beaches in California. The Santa Monica pier is also fun to walk and there are lots of cool places to eat where you might be able to share a table with someone from anywhere in the world. There are lots of places to buy souvenirs too. Sunsets are spectacular.

What could possibly disappoint?!? Beautifully clean uncrowded beaches in the SoCal sunshine, plenty of parking and only a short stroll from the bars and restaurants of Ocean Drive or the shopping and coffee of 3rd Street Promenade!

I absolutely love the beach, so obviously I HAD to check out Santa Monica while I was in Los Angeles! it was a clean beach with great waves and good restaurants as well as shopping. It is very touristy, so if that isn't your thing, it's not the place for you.

Santa Monica is a great getaway from the city. If you are a local or just in LA visiting and don't have too much time/or a car, Santa Monica is the beach to hit up. It is accessible by Metro using the blue Expo line however driving is also simple but parking can get pricey as prices fluctuate during peak times. The pier offers fantastic views of the surrounding areas, quick eats, souvenir shops, fishing, a killer arcade (old and new games) and a mini theme park including a ferris wheel and rollercoaster. The rides get pricey ($6/ride) however if you are to choose one, take the ferris wheel at night or sunset. The beach is usually crowded near the pier but walk north or south a bit and you will find plenty of space including exercise areas, volleyball nets, and bathrooms. Off the beach, a few blocks east of Ocean Avenue, downtown Santa Monica offers a great shopping area with name brands like H&M, Victoria Secret, Johnny Rockets, and a movie theatre.

TIP: Sunset is a great time. You will find many photographers, couples, families, and locals on the sand to watch the sunset.

Fun fact: This is the pier where they filmed Lost Boys!
Show less
Beaufiful bay and nice sea side city

The Santa Monica Bay is extremely beautiful, stretching from Malibu to Palos Verdes. Many beautiful beaches to choose from with great views of the city and even Catalina island. After driving or walking on the beach, you can go to the Santa Monica Pier and people watch, shop, eat or enjoy carnival rides. Up from the pier is the 3rd Street Promenade in the city of Santa Monica. Lots of shops and good restaurants to partake. Fun place to go for the entire family.

Santa Monica Bay is a beautiful bay with stunning beaches but activities here can be expensive. You can walk from here to Venice beach which makes a nice stroll as well.

Santa Monica Bay is great beach area!! (I live further south) This location is amazing on the water in Santa Monica. There is so much to see and do here. Shopping, eating (especially The Lobster on the pier), etc.

This area is a must see, especially for someone who has never been to LA. It was about a 20 to 30 minute drive from downtown LA. The pier has lots of interesting characters, souvenir shops and kiosks. There are restaurants as well with indoor and outdoor seating. The amusement section is small, but children and adults alike can have a good time with the rides, or the carnival atmosphere.

Yes, with 72 F or warmer up to 84F this is the place to be, roler blades, bikes, you name it, restaurants and of course the famous beach. come and play. recommended MeuterMedia

Park anywhere you like to take in this lovely coastline! Pay lots are abundant, but so too is ample free parking up Temescal Canyon, below Pali High (a locals secret). You can enjoy the Bay during the day for all the right outdoor reasons- bike or skate for miles on the smooth bike path or choose to walk in the water along the shore as you beach comb for shells and other treasures. Did you know sunset over the coast is a great photo op, too?! All of this is a wonderful, relaxing escape from day to day hassles! This has been my family’s go to place for 3 generations and the magic still holds true!

Just a lovely place to hang out.
Really enjoyed shopping at Santa Monica Place. Lots of history in the architecture and street art. Lovely arcades full of restaurants.
A must do when ending the Route 66

it was one of my child memories to visit this pier when finishing the Route 66 on a motorcycle. Did it and it was worth it. After a very long day traveling looking at the sea and feeling the vibe it boosts all the energy levels lost during the whole day. Cant wait to go back.

Like the East Coast Boardwalk on a small scale

Fun pier to walk out on; lovely long beach with views to swim or sunbathe on; busy times bring lots of people but the whole thing is a happening CA style. We enjoyed the whole scene. Go out to the end of the pier...it feels like you are really in the ocean!

nice beach to hang out and have some fun with family. There are many shops around the area. It is difficult to park.

Every city in Los Angeles has it's own look, rhythm and dress code and Santa Monica is no different. If you are a woman it's minimal makeup, tanned and no bra. If you are a guy it's tattoos if you are younger, a little more muscle than the normal guy and some expensive if you know what you're looking for piece of clothing or accessory. There are no exceptions. You may also pass some transients and sadly economically displaced individuals on the walk from wherever you parked your car to the bay. Be wary of anyone who looks "out of it" because looks don't deceive.

Now you are at the beach, and things literally start to get cool. The heat of Los Angeles is replaced by a beautiful just right breeze. The indigenous look of Santa Monica residents is replaced by having the diversity of the world right in front of you. It is a heady mix of tourists from around the world and the residents of Los Angeles who have come to escape the heat of Los Angeles, their busy lives and just have fun, fun, fun. The beach is clean and well patrolled by lifeguards. There are bathrooms on the pier which you should probably use before the family sets foot on the sand and you can just have a great day enjoying your friends and loved ones. Look for any signs and/or red flags that warn you of places not to swim or if you plan on doing a spot of fishing what you should not eat. Afterward, take a walk to Venice, or go eat at one of the many tasty eateries in Santa Monica that cater to all tastes and price points. So wear what the heck you want, take water, sunscreen and comfy shoes for your feet and have a ball. That is what Santa Monica is all about.
Show less
This is the place I went to clear my head - a bit of fresh air while dipping my toes in the cold water
We went to Santa Monica for a day out it was such a great place to visit and lots to see and do. Well worth going to.

Great place to visit. The Pier and attractions are worth the trip. Take a walk along the beach to Muscle Beach. We also went at night where one of California's famous fogs moved in and you could not see 10 foot in front of you. It then cleared after an hour, an incredible sight.

Great place to visit and shop. A lot of great places to dine in. It is also a great family getaway and I would definitely recommend it.

Great Stroll along the pier and beach.
you have to go out on the concrete walkway to the beach edge. It was The day after Christmas so it was a little cold, but the views were spectacular!

Santa Monica is one of my favourite places in the LA area - the nostalgia of the pier , the food options and the shopping are all great.

It’s busy and very touched by human hand but you’d still never know that LA was just a few miles along the boulevard

Such a beautiful place to see. We hired a bike at Venice Beach, rode over the pier & spent about an hour there. Not really anywhere on the pier to site down and eat however there is plenty a few minutes walk away.

I was in Santa Monica Bay 20 years ago when I was much younger and sort of like it. However, in the recent visit, I feel it is not as good as I remember. Possibly it is also because the day I visited (the Saturday before New Years' Eve), I feel it is overcrowded and the atmosphere is too cheesy.

The beach was crowded but the water did not too tempting for swimming. The beach itself is also not specially scenic.

If this is your first time to Los Angeles (or, even the first time to the United States), it can be an interesting experience and a good photo opportunity. For people who are local and been to LA many times, there are other better (more scenic) beaches to visit.

My husband, son (age 48), and I wanted to see Santa Monica Pier on a recent trip to West Hollywood to visit our younger son, so we went. We are from Sonoma Co and used to the San Francisco pier and the Monterey pier. I expected to see something like the Monterey pier. It is not!
The beach is beautiful and seems to go on for miles, but the pier itself had a lot of cheap touristy stuff on it, no restaurants, and an amusement park next to it. There were also 3 "preachers" along the pier.
If that is what you are looking for, then the pier would be fine. We had hoped to find a nice seafood restaurant on the pier, as there are in Monterey, so it was a let down. We decided that it was not a place to which we wished to return.
We went back to the Westlake shopping center and ate at a restaurant called the Italy, which had excellent Italian food.

nice warm sand, bring your drink to cool down. nice sun tan is recommended. do not worry about getting wet

With a small amusement park on the pier, the vibe at Santa Monica is quite teen-ish. Yet it's a beautiful beach with a lovely backdrop of hills. So many options to eat and shop makes it an ideal day for a day out.

OK, for visitors...DO NOT swim too close to the S. M. Pier. Bacteria from birds all around the pier is in the ocean and not great for humans. That said, it's a must visit. A lot of traffic on weekends. Great restaurants nearby. Rent a bike and ride along the path past Venice to Marina Del Ray.

We visited this location in Dec 17, and it was very quite. There was heaps of parking available. The Pier was great we stayed to the evening so the kids could goto the fair. A must see if in the LA area.
Nice beach with lot of playing options. Good restaurants for kids and all type of age people. Enough parking on peak hours too. Everywhere fun and people are busy with activities.
Great place to go to the pier, beach, farmer's market, and eat!

We love spending a half day or more in Santa Monica. We often go to the Saturday Farmer's market on Arizona and get organic produce. We love to go to the pier and walk around, sit on the beach and make a sand castle, and eat at Bubba Gumps. It's a great place to spend the day!

This is about the bay, not the pier.

I thought that the title of this "place" was kind of funny -- "Santa Monica Bay", but the address is for the pier. Well, the pier is fun, but that's a review for another day. This is about the bay itself, the long crescent that runs down from Malibu to Palos Verdes, that contains a host of sea life, sailboats, fishing boats, usually an oil tanker or two, with an astonishing amount of Marine traffic on its western edge.

There are some key geographic markers for the landlubbers and sailers alike. For me, it starts at the north with the Malibu pier. Some brave souls will anchor nearby, as the depth is relatively shallow and take a kayak in, but there's no official landing: you'll have to surf in and beach the kayak. Then there's the Santa Monica Pier, (the address above). That has a lot of history, and still has the old-time 20's vibe to it. If you're out to sea, you'll be sure to notice the seals and sea lions that hang out on the buoy near the pier, and watch out for the submerged shoals north of the pier. It's a good marker--we like to sail up just past the pier, and tack back down toward the Marina. If the wind is right, we'll set the spinnaker just to put on a show for the kids on the pier.

Along this stretch as well, you'll see parasailers (especially in summer) being towed by speedboats along the beach, which is also a pretty sight. Some other marine life to look out for include Pacific sunfish basking near the surface, and not infrequently a curious dolphin or three. And if you're fishing, you'll probably meet a seal trying to steal your catch.

Further south, there's the Venice pier, and the Marina Del Rey harbor entrance, marked by a giant American flag. There's a distinct aroma here, as a large colony of sea lions can be found hanging out on the breakwater year round. Further south, you'll almost certainly pass an oil tanker riding at anchor near the El Segundo refinery pipeline -- if you're on a keel boat at low tide, be careful of the snags! You'll pass under the LAX flight path on your way to King Harbor, which is a fun stop. Pro tip: you can reserve a mooring at basin 3 for 24 bucks a night should you need to stop on your way up or down the coast.

Southern tip ends with Malaga Cove, named after one of my favorite cities in Spain. The Palos Verdes cliffs rise up, covered with some of the most expensive real estate in the Los Angeles area.

You can get charters and daytrips for sightseeing, fishing and whalewatching on the Bay from Marina Del Rey and King Harbor. It's the fastest way to get out of the city, and deep into nature within at least three hundred miles. Or you can just rent a Sabot or Lazer, or paddleboard and just tool around the marina. One note of caution: paddleboarders, please look out for the boats: they don't have brakes! Crossing in front of someone's bow could lead to less than optimum outcomes!

Here’s the good: It’s really fun to walk on the pier. Take a ride on the merry-go-round and then have a great hamburger at Pier Burger. For a high-end experience, have martinis and lobster at The Lobster.

The bad: There has been a lot of crime on that beach and under The Pier. The ocean has tested as one of the dirtiest. It’s not safe at night to be on the beach at all.
Show less

Santa Monica is a friendly place to visit. The Pier is the main attraction. Lots of rides for the kids, and many restaurants within walking distance at all cost levels. If you swim it is best to walk a hundred yards away from the pier before you put down your blanket. Water is cleaner away from the pier. Water is never Mediterranean warm in the Pacific. Don't be surprised if it's a bit chilly. The Promenade is three blocks from the Pier. Take a walk down the shops. The view from the top of Ocean Blvd is spectacular. Venice is ten minutes down the shore, and Malibu is thirty minutes up the shore. You can ride a bike on a path next to the ocean for miles, if you wish. Or take a hike in the mountains above Malibu. It's a friendly place.
Show less
Great place to spend a day alone or with family/friends. Many places to take pictures and near to the Hollywood area (if you have a car). Totally recomended.
took grandkids on outing during school vacation
beautiful grounds , and views , lots of activities for children , worthwhile to go , small aquarium for $5 entrance fee
We visited in may 2017 & stayed there for 2 nights , hotel staff is pleasant & helpfull , it's ideally located.
Sun,Beach and Sand.. Take your stuff lay on the beach and have fun ! its the best beach ever in LA !

Beautiful place to bike ride to or rptake a walk along beach and out to pier. We didn't have time to go on amusements, but looked like lots of fun. Lovely day for a walk, and not to far from shopping centre

Santa Monica, and every other beach I visited during the week I spent on the west coast, blows away all expectations one may have based on what can be seen on television or the internet. Physically go and see for yourself!

Santa Monica pier is always fun for swimming, sunbathing, eating, drinking, shopping, surfing, fishing, and...carnival rides! Parking at the pier is reasonable and will save you loads of time. Many tourists don't realize you can park right on the pier and save your walking for the attractions.

這裡很美！但水蠻冷的！ 基本上只待1、2小時的話推薦將車停在橋上，因為不貴的！ 而停周遭大型停車場反而超貴。 （麥當勞旁那個停車場）
Water was cold, but the sunset here is really beautiful! You can also have the colorful ferries to be your photo shoot background.

Parking is not easy to find during the weekend. Highly recommend to park "on the pier", because the fee is actually not bad compared to the public one( next to the Macdonald), ifffff you only will stay on the pier for about couple of hours.
Watch out your kids, because the sea waves here are very crazy and dangerous.
We didn't try the restaurant here called water grill or something, but I heard it was a good place. I might give it a try next time when we visit here!

Nice big beach. Small waves but watch for under current. Plenty of firm and soft sand. Gets very busy in summer. Santa Monica Pier nearby and a bit touristy. Plenty of homeless around but they keep to themselves.
well worth the trip as well as the pier you can also go to Venice beach at once which is a plus. parking however is over priced and you don't realiase to after the beaches actual parking is cheaper.

Santa Monica provides an array of options regarding shopping and eating but it is very hustle and bustle. Traffic is congested. After being rushed through Hollywood in the morning we spent a relaxing afternoon in Santa Monica. The pier is pleasant to walk along the pier look at the scenery and soak up the atmosphere. This is of course where Baywatch was filmed unfortunately no sign of Pamela Anderson!. This was our first full day in California and i liked Santa Monica very much. It has an old world charm about it. Do not be alarmed by the vagrants you see walking around they do not seem to bother anybody. After a walk we went into the town and found a splendid English pub just up the road called The Olde King's Head. You can sit outside in the sunshine watch the scenery and drink draught Boddingtons at 8 US$ a pint!. Better then Bud Lite!. Great pub in a nice town!. Well worth a visit!.

Most people come to the Pier where you ll be met by various vendors and typical tourist attractions, amusement park, ferris wheel, hamburger stands, clowns, sketch artists, etc. Very few people venture to go down to the beach, which has nothing special to offer, Other nearby beaches proved to be superior. Spend 30-45 going down and up the Pier take all the selfies you want and then head for downtown Santa Monica just few blocks away. Enjoy the sun.

Visiting Santa Monica Pier was one of the highlights of our trip. It was a great day trip and my 2 kids (ages 6 and under) enjoyed it. There lots to see in a relatively small area so you can just park in one spot and walk around for the whole day.

You can rent a bike down near the famed pier and just peddle your way up and along... Easy and fun and the view is right there at your finger tips!
A must for anyone who just loves to get out in the air on a glorious Californian winters day!

We walked along Venice Beach to Santa Monica Pier! Quite a way in the heat but soooo lovely. There was a lovely atmosphere here so relaxing. It was a great place to visit want to live there!

Santa Monica beach captures much of what So Cal beaches are about. Lots of people, cold waters (typically), and not much rain.

Traveler Tip: I've lived in So Cal most of my life and grew up going to the beach. Junior Lifeguards as a child and then surfing multiple times a week or just going for a quick jog as an adult. Santa Monica has a nice blend of activities with the boardwalk and 3rd street promenade so I'd say it's a pretty good choice for someone visiting CA and looking to get the full experience.

I'm a fellow traveler so I appreciate when other people have given me tips/recommendations while in a new city. If this information is helpful, please let me know by hitting the like button. Even if this review helps only one traveler then it's worth it to know I'm contributing towards making someone's experience better, giving to the global community, and paying it forward. Safe Travels!

Wandering along the walkway and pier, swimming, biking and enjoying food and music along the Promenade. As of a year or so ago, those lovely days are no longer . The once fresh breezes blowing ocean air are now blowing the inescapable smoke of a horrifyingly ridiculous amount off hookahs, cigarettes, marijuana and e- cigarettes. This was one of our stops on the Los Angeles city tour so unfortunately didn't have a lot of time did manage to walk down the pier and walk on the beach the area looks very nice lots of restaurants and aparrently the end of Route 66 on the pier would suggest spending a bit longer here and Venice beach not far away either

Iconic and worth a visit! Free parking under 90 minutes

Keep your visit short and you could enjoy the Santa Monica Pier and Beach for FREE. All public lots off of 2nd, 4th, 5th are FREE under 90 minutes. All the beach parking lots are about $12/day or part thereof. My kids love the fitness obstacle course on the south side of the pier. You can see alot of folks doing their tight rope, Cirque du Soleil type acrobatics or just gymnastics conditioning all around. Rent bikes, go on rides on the pier or just buy junk food. It's fun if you feel like dealing with the crowds. Groupon recently had an all day pass for the pier rides. Avoid coming on Saturday, it's just nuts. Do Friday afternoon or Sunday late in the day to have a better chance at finding a decent parking spot.

The sand is nice and soft and white and clean.

It's a beach and pier with an atmosphere of its own. Very distinct, quaintly charming yet teeming with visitors of all ages at all times. There are attractions down the pier on both sides of the wooden path for children and adults . Enchanting music, mouth watering smells of all kinds of food from several stalls , ferry wheels and merry-go-rounds with squeeling children on the one side and those getting sprayed by playful beach waves on the other only add to the magic. Please go with some time on hand - you would not want to return !

a real nice, clean beach and the pier is a must go to take some good pictures. And surely a place for Route 66 fans - as this is the western end of Route 66 :)
I Left My Heart in Santa Monica

Few know the historic significance of Santa Monica Bay. Spanish explorer, Juan Rodriguez Cabrillo commanded the first European expedition to the west coast of the America. He dropped anchor in Santa Monica in 1542, a mere fifty years after Columbus sailed the ocean blue to the new world in 1492. There was no Panama canal then so he had to navigate the treacherous water around the south tip of South America.

Fast forward to modern times. One might wonder why Los Angeles was not first settled with Santa Monica as the epicenter. The rich and famous discovered it, including William Randolph Hurst who built his mistress Marion Davies a palatial mansion right on the beach. The mansion is long gong but the olympic sized pool remains open to the public along with her guest house -- which by today's standards could be considered a modest mansion -- also open to the public.

The best place to appreciate the panoramic vista of the bay is along Pacific Palisades Park. Lined by palm trees, it is in my opinion the most picturesque spot in Santa Monica if not all of Los Angeles. It begins at Pico Blvd. and winds north all the way up to San Vicente Blvd. From there you can view from left to right, Palos Verdes peninsula, Catalina Island, the iconic Santa Monica Pier (with roller coaster and ferris wheel at the end) and Malibu.

Don't miss the 3rd Street Promenade mall that begins at the famous Miramar Hotel (every movie star from the golden age and luminaries from all over the world have stayed there -- and where I honeymooned). Walk south to Santa Monica Place outdoor mall.

There are many great restaurants that adorn Ocean Avenue, with open window views of Palisades Park and the bay. If you are lucky, you may see a pod of Killer Whales that call the bay their home.
Show less
It is a nice place to people watch and look at the ocean from a world famous pier.

It's free to walk to and enter if you are staying in Santa Monica. I'd park at the Third Street Promenade parking (free), earlier in the day the better, and walk down the driveway towards the Pier. It's a nice pier with attractions and rides for the kids. On a clear day you can see as far north as Pt. Dume and and far south as the Santa Catalina Islands. As the day progresses though, it becomes slightly sketchy as a certain element starts to show up. Nothing to be alarmed about, but definitely more adult at that point. If you are staying in the City, take the Expo train line, which goes directly there.

If you are in the area, this one is a must see. It's iconic. It's beautiful and dirty all at the same time. Glad my daughter and I were able to take it all in and stroll down the beach to the next stop. The walkway between the beaches was fun and we enjoyed people watching.

Santa Monica Bay - Needs Our Clean-up Efforts

Though you can't compare the beaches of Hawaii in any way shape or form to those on our Southern California shores, it was a sad day to visit Santa Monica Bay (far from the Pier - because it's normally cleaner), to find the water to be very dirty and littered with trash and bits of tar/oil from the rigs off-shore.

I've previously enjoyed coming here - close to LifeGuard Station 24-27, for the gentler waves so you can swim in the ocean, but sadly it's been a tough summer here and we need to clean our bay - again :(
